*div1 type="summary"* *p*Austin to James F. Perry, April 22, 1833. His intentions to obtain repeal of the law of April 6, 1830, and to get permission for Texas to adopt a constitution.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**date_mentioned n="04-22-1833">April 22. 12 o'clock A. M. 1833.*/date_mentioned**/p* *p**person_mentioned*J. F. Perry*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p*There is, I am told, some uneasiness that I shall [not?] insist on the approbation of the constitution as formed by the late convention— I shall try and get the law of*date_mentioned n="04-06-1830"> 6 April 1830 */date_mentioned*repealed and a declaration that the *person_mentioned*people of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* may legally convene in convention to make a constitution— This much I expect to effect and no more— It is very evident that no act of mine can bind the *person_mentioned*people of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned*— What I do, if anything, shall be subject to their approbation of course—no one need have any fears that I will compromise *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*improperly— The interest of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*is my interest— Unfortunately we have some *person_mentioned*personal parties */person_mentioned*amongst us—but this is an evil that will correct itself in time— I will write you all frequently—have confidence in me, untill you see what I do and then approve or punish as I merit—*/p*
*p*I start in five minutes.*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*S. F. Austin*/person_mentioned**/p*
*/div1*
